Content: What is the narrator's primary motivation for continuing to visit Jim?

A.Choice: He wants Jim to ask him to help with the experiments.

Key.Rationale: No information suggests the narrator wanted to help Jim with experiments.

B.Choice: He enjoys watching Jim manage several tasks at once.

Key.Rationale: No evidence indicates Jim works on more than one task at a time.

C.Choice: He thinks spending time with Jim will make him smarter.

Key.Rationale: No evidence suggests the narrator wanted to learn by watching Jim.

D.Choice: He likes witnessing the moments when Jim is surprised.

Key.Rationale: The narrator would just watch Jim and wait for him to say “Woah!”

Content: Why is Jim's demonstration with the jawbreaker important to the plot?

F.Choice: It shows the narrator that many scientific concepts are not complicated.

Key.Rationale: The only scientific concept identified in the story is protons.

G.Choice: It allows the narrator to experience a moment of understanding.

Key.Rationale: The jawbreaker demonstration helps the narrator understand protons.

H.Choice: It encourages the narrator to develop his own scientific theory about protons.

Key.Rationale: The narrator does not develop a theory about protons.

J.Choice: It gives the narrator an opportunity to help Jim with one of his projects.

Key.Rationale: The narrator does not help Jim with any projects.

Content: Read the dictionary entry below.

:box:digest \dī-'jest\ v
1. to convert food into absorbable form
2. to think over in order to absorb
3. to arrange in a methodical order; classify
4. to reduce to a summary
Which definition most closely matches the way the word d͟i͟g͟e͟s͟t is used in paragraph 28?

A.Choice: Definition 1

Key.Rationale: Paragraph 28 is focused on information instead of food.

B.Choice: Definition 2

Key.Rationale: Paragraph 28 refers to the information the narrator was considering.

C.Choice: Definition 3

Key.Rationale: Paragraph 28 does not indicate the narrator or Jim organized information.

D.Choice: Definition 4

Key.Rationale: No information was summarized in the story.

Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 4.
:box:And he would explain it to me, and though I couldn't really understand, still I would feel something, a cool fizzing behind my ears, because I was feeding off his astonishment.
The sensory language in this sentence highlights the narrator's  —

F.Choice: optimism

Key.Rationale: Paragraph 4 does not indicate the narrator feels optimistic.

G.Choice: confusion

Key.Rationale: Paragraph 4 does not indicate the narrator feels confused.

H.Choice: excitement

Key.Rationale: The narrator says he was “feeding off [Jim's] astonishment.”

J.Choice: discomfort

Key.Rationale: Paragraph 4 does not indicate the narrator's discomfort.

Content: What does the simile in paragraph 3 suggest about Jim?

A.Choice: He wishes he knew someone who shared his passion.

Key.Rationale: The simile does not suggest Jim wanted to know someone who shared his passion.

B.Choice: He approaches his work with intense focus.

Key.Rationale: The simile compares Jim to a play-by-play announcer describing a game.

C.Choice: He is interested in both science and sports.

Key.Rationale: There is no evidence Jim was interested in sports.

D.Choice: He usually makes up experiments as they occur to him.

Key.Rationale: There is no indication in the story that Jim makes up experiments.

Content: The setting is important to the plot because it is where the narrator  —

F.Choice: realizes he is good at scientific investigation

Key.Rationale: The narrator does not undertake any scientific investigations.

G.Choice: can study with minimal interruptions

Key.Rationale: The narrator does not go to Jim's house to study.

H.Choice: has interesting discussions with Jim

Key.Rationale: The narrator and Jim have an interesting conversation about protons.

J.Choice: works with Jim to solve problems

Key.Rationale: The narrator does not help Jim solve problems in the story.

Content: Which of these is an important idea expressed in the excerpt?

A.Choice: People must start working toward their goals at a young age to achieve their dreams.

Key.Rationale: Neither character is working toward goals to achieve a dream.

B.Choice: Honesty and openness allow deep friendships to develop.

Key.Rationale: The characters do not develop a deep friendship.

C.Choice: True understanding can take place only through quiet reflection.

Key.Rationale: The narrator's only understanding comes from a conversation with Jim.

D.Choice: Some people influence the lives of others by introducing them to new ideas.

Key.Rationale: Jim introduces the narrator to the concept of protons being a part of everything.

Content: Read the information about the origin of the word r͟e͟p͟l͟e͟n͟i͟s͟h.
:box:from Latin plenus, meaning “full”
This information helps the reader understand that r͟e͟p͟l͟e͟n͟i͟s͟h͟e͟d in paragraph 2 means  —

F.Choice: built up again

Key.Rationale: “Full” refers to collecting and storing seeds in the vault to prevent them from disappearing.

G.Choice: highly valued

Key.Rationale: The paragraph is about the quantity of available seeds.

H.Choice: properly managed

Key.Rationale: The paragraph does not mention the process for managing seeds.

J.Choice: correctly used

Key.Rationale: The paragraph does not mention the correct use of the seeds.

Content: The main reason for building the vault in an isolated, underground location was to  —

A.Choice: ensure that it would be difficult for people to retrieve seeds they put in the vault

Key.Rationale: People cannot retrieve seeds from the vault.

B.Choice: decrease the amount of power necessary to keep the seeds at a cold temperature

Key.Rationale: The climate keeps the chamber at a constant temperature.

C.Choice: minimize the number of people that would be necessary to monitor the vault

Key.Rationale: No one monitors the automated facility.

D.Choice: prevent outside events from damaging the contents of the vault

Key.Rationale: The purpose of the chamber is “keeping a treasure safe” and “untouched.”

Content: Read these sentences from the selection.
:box:“We are losing biodiversity every day,” Fowler explains. “It is kind of a drip, drip, drip — it's also inevitable.”
The comparison in Fowler's statement helps the reader understand that  —

F.Choice: few people realize the consequences of losing seed varieties

Key.Rationale: Fowler's statement doesn't address the consequences of losing seed varieties.

G.Choice: seed varieties are lost slowly, but the loss accumulates over time

Key.Rationale: Fowler's statement refers to the “drip, drip, drip” of biodiversity, and the idea that this loss is inevitable.

H.Choice: many seed varieties have been lost as a result of natural disasters

Key.Rationale: Fowler's statement indicates a steady loss of biodiversity, not loss due to natural disasters.

J.Choice: scientists think seed varieties could be saved through improved agricultural practices

Key.Rationale: No evidence indicates improved practices would save seed varieties.

Content: Based on the selection, the reader can conclude that the seed vault  —

A.Choice: stores rare seeds more securely than common seeds

Key.Rationale: Rare seeds and common seeds are stored in the same vault.

B.Choice: can be toured by visitors at any time

Key.Rationale: The entry to the vault is a guarded tunnel with no full-time staff, and no single person has the codes to gain entry.

C.Choice: is maintained by several different countries

Key.Rationale: The seeds come from around the world, but no evidence indicates different countries maintain the vault.

D.Choice: provides a unique and vital resource

Key.Rationale: The vault contains “the greatest collection of biodiversity in the world,” and it is important to the preservation of the world.

Content: Read the dictionary entry below.

:box:critical \'kri-ti-kəl\ adj
1. relating to a stage of illness
2. tending to evaluate unfavorably
3. needed to serve a purpose
4. using careful judgment
Which definition best fits how c͟r͟i͟t͟i͟c͟a͟l is used in paragraph 1?

F.Choice: Definition 1

Key.Rationale: Paragraph 1 does not address the concept of illness.

G.Choice: Definition 2

Key.Rationale: Paragraph 1 describes the vault but does not include the evaluation of it.

H.Choice: Definition 3

Key.Rationale: Paragraph 1 identifies the storage of seeds within the vault as crucial to the survival of mankind.

J.Choice: Definition 4

Key.Rationale: Paragraph 1 does not indicate judgment in relation to the vault.

Content: Paragraph 4 is mostly about  —

A.Choice: how countries decide which seeds to send to the Svalbard Seed Vault

Key.Rationale: Paragraph 4 indicates no decision process for depositing seeds in the vault.

B.Choice: why Norway decided to sponsor the construction of the Svalbard Seed Vault

Key.Rationale: Paragraph 4 indicates no reason for Norway deciding to sponsor the construction of the vault.

C.Choice: the process for shipping new seeds to the Svalbard Seed Vault

Key.Rationale: The process for shipping seeds to the vault is not addressed in paragraph 4.

D.Choice: the diversity of the contents stored in the Svalbard Seed Vault

Key.Rationale: Paragraph 4 refers to seeds from Mexico, Nigeria, North America, and from the Aztecs and Incas.

Content: The problem–solution organization of paragraph 2 helps the author emphasize the  —

F.Choice: difficulties other seed vaults have encountered in the past

Key.Rationale: There are no other seed vaults to compare the Svalbard Seed Vault to.

G.Choice: severity of the decrease in seed varieties

Key.Rationale: Paragraph 2 indicates scientists are concerned that certain types of food could disappear from stores and kitchens.

H.Choice: reasons some seeds disappear more quickly than others

Key.Rationale: Paragraph 2 does not indicate the rate that seeds disappear.

J.Choice: best way to prepare for a natural disaster

Key.Rationale: Paragraph 2 does not address ways to prepare for a natural disaster.

Content: What is the best summary of the selection?

A.Choice: On the fourth anniversary of the Svalbard Seed Vault, rare seeds from North America and ancient grains were added to the vault. The vault contains many seeds with special genetic traits that may be useful in the future. Visitors are often awed by the biodiversity secured in the seed vault.

Key.Rationale: This summary is incomplete. It does not include information about the purpose or location of the vault.

B.Choice: The seeds in the Svalbard Seed Vault are stored in rows of sealed boxes in a highly secure vault. The vault is made of steel, located inside a mountain, and requires the use of many codes to enter. The cold environment preserves the seeds even if power to the facility is lost.

Key.Rationale: The information in this summary is too general. In addition, the summary does not include the location of the vault or the reason for building it.

C.Choice: The Svalbard Seed Vault is located in an isolated region of Norway. The vault was created to protect varieties of seeds from being lost and to preserve them for later use. Many rare seeds have already been sent to the vault and have contributed to the effort to maintain biodiversity.

Key.Rationale: This summary includes the most important ideas from the selection.

D.Choice: The Svalbard Seed Vault is considered the greatest store of crop diversity to date. Efforts to build the seed vault began when scientists noticed that crop variety had decreased significantly in recent years. The vault contains many rare and ancient seeds.

Key.Rationale: This summary is general and incomplete. It does not address the importance of maintaining biodiversity.

Content: Which statement is supported by the illustration of the vault that appears after paragraph 3?

F.Choice: The seeds are housed in a highly secure location.

Key.Rationale: The illustration shows the secure tunnel behind the steel door.

G.Choice: Many donors help finance the maintenance of the vault.

Key.Rationale: The illustration does not indicate how the vault will be maintained.

H.Choice: Many people understand the importance of the vault.

Key.Rationale: The illustration does not indicate an understanding of the importance of the vault.

J.Choice: Seeds are safer in separate chambers than in one open area.

Key.Rationale: The illustration does not show that separate vault chambers would impact the safety of seeds.

Content: The author wrote this selection most likely to  —

A.Choice: describe the efforts to prevent the Leaning Tower of Pisa from collapsing

Key.Rationale: The author describes several methods used to keep the tower from leaning.

B.Choice: convince people that the Leaning Tower of Pisa is worth saving

Key.Rationale: The author does not include persuasive language to indicate that he wanted to convince people of the value of the tower.

C.Choice: explain why the earliest attempts to maintain the Leaning Tower of Pisa were unsuccessful

Key.Rationale: The selection does not include reasons why early attempts to maintain the tower were not successful.

D.Choice: demonstrate why the Leaning Tower of Pisa is not safe to enter

Key.Rationale: Experts now agree that the tower should be stable for another 300 years.

Content: Which detail from the selection explains why one attempt to fix the lean made the tower lean even more?

F.Choice: Cables and weights were installed to stabilize the tower's lean.

Key.Rationale: Cables and weights did not cause the tower to lean more.

G.Choice: The tower continued to lean even after a bell chamber was placed on the tower's north side.

Key.Rationale: The placement of the bell tower was not an effort to fix the lean, but to keep it from progressing.

H.Choice: A concrete leak made the tower's foundation more unstable.

Key.Rationale: The injection of concrete into the foundation resulted in concrete seeping under it, making the tower lean even more.

J.Choice: Soil was removed from beneath the north end of the tower to make the ground more even.

Key.Rationale: The removal of soil did not level the ground or resolve the problem completely.

Content: Which sentence from the selection is an assertion made by the author?

A.Choice: In 1990 experts determined that the tower was dangerously close to toppling over, and public entry into the tower was prohibited.

Key.Rationale: This event from 1900 is a fact, not an assertion.

B.Choice: One commission even suggested attaching helium balloons to the tower to hold it up, but the suggestion was never actually attempted.

Key.Rationale: This suggestion about using helium balloons is a fact, not an assertion.

C.Choice: An international commission of historians and experts then began an effort to save the tower.

Key.Rationale: The information about a commission of experts and historians trying to save the tower is a fact, not an assertion.

D.Choice: If the tower leans significantly more, however, architectural experts and historians will surely once again come to the aid of the magnificent Leaning Tower of Pisa.

Key.Rationale: The assertion about historians and experts trying to save the tower at a future date is an assumption based upon past events.

Content: Which idea does the information in paragraph 2 support?

F.Choice: The tower was difficult to build without modern technology.

Key.Rationale: Paragraph 2 does not address whether the tower was difficult to build without modern technology.

G.Choice: The problem with the tower was evident early in its construction.

Key.Rationale: The tower had started to tilt by the time construction of the third and fourth floors of the tower had begun.

H.Choice: The addition of the bell tower caused the tower to lean more.

Key.Rationale: The tower continued to lean but not more than it did before placement of the bell tower.

J.Choice: The construction of the tower was a slower process than expected.

Key.Rationale: Paragraph 2 does not address a timeline for construction of the tower.

Content: The reader can conclude that the tower will most likely  —

A.Choice: need to be monitored and maintained for as long as it continues to stand

Key.Rationale: If the tower leans significantly more, experts and historians will probably try again to stop the lean.

B.Choice: be completely straightened using technology that will become available in the future

Key.Rationale: The selection does not address how technology might influence efforts to straighten the tower in the future.

C.Choice: become more magnificent as it continues to lean

Key.Rationale: The design of the tower has not changed as a result of the efforts to straighten it.

D.Choice: help experts solve structural problems with other buildings

Key.Rationale: The selection does not address any connection of the efforts to stop the leaning of the tower to any structural problems with other buildings.

Content: How does the author support the idea that the Cutty Sark was once considered a technologically advanced ship?

F.Choice: By mentioning the sailing records the ship had set

Key.Rationale: The Cutty Sark was one of the most advanced clippers of its time, setting new speed records in the 1880s.

G.Choice: By stating the dimensions of the ship

Key.Rationale: The selection does not address the dimensions of the ship.

H.Choice: By explaining the ship's role in the tea trade

Key.Rationale: The hull made the Cutty Sark ideal for use with tea trade, but the ship's role in tea trade is not addressed.

J.Choice: By telling about the ship's later uses

Key.Rationale: The selection details the restoration and display of the Cutty Sark, but not the later uses of the ship.

Content: How does the author organize the selection?

A.Choice: By contrasting the design of the Cutty Sark with that of other ships and then providing evidence supporting the idea that the design of the Cutty Sark was superior

Key.Rationale: The selection does not contain information about other ships.

B.Choice: By explaining why the Cutty Sark was an important ship and then describing efforts to preserve it

Key.Rationale: The Cutty Sark was used for training WWII naval officers, and a trust was created to restore the ship as a museum in London.

C.Choice: By providing examples of how the Cutty Sark had been a useful ship in the past and then discussing how opinions about the Cutty Sark have changed over time

Key.Rationale: No changes of opinion about the ship are addressed in the selection.

D.Choice: By summarizing the main problem that the Cutty Sark encountered and then relating how the problem was solved

Key.Rationale: The selection provides a historical record of the Cutty Sark as a valuable ship for the tea industry in London and of its restoration and display for public viewing.

Content: What is the author's main purpose for writing this selection?

F.Choice: To demonstrate how the Cutty Sark helped a country's economy

Key.Rationale: The author does not describe the Cutty Sark as being important to the economy of a country.

G.Choice: To convince the reader that the Cutty Sark was the fastest vessel of its time

Key.Rationale: The selection includes information about faster steam vessels rising in popularity, which rendered the Cutty Sark obsolete.

H.Choice: To explain that the Cutty Sark is an important part of London's history

Key.Rationale: The Cutty Sark remained important throughout London's history.

J.Choice: To identify why a special exhibit had to be created to display the Cutty Sark

Key.Rationale: The manner of display is a detail linked to the ship being raised to allow a view of the hull shape.

Content: The photograph at the end of the selection is included to  —

A.Choice: illustrate why the Cutty Sark needed renovation

Key.Rationale: The photograph does not show the interior or exterior condition of the ship.

B.Choice: highlight the Cutty Sark's historical significance

Key.Rationale: The photograph does not show anything related to the Cutty Sark's historical significance.

C.Choice: indicate the number of people who can visit the Cutty Sark each day

Key.Rationale: The photograph does not show how many people can view the Cutty Sark each day.

D.Choice: show how a defining feature of the Cutty Sark is displayed

Key.Rationale: The photograph shows the raised hull of the Cutty Sark, which made the ship special.

Content: According to the selections, the Leaning Tower of Pisa is different from the Cutty Sark because  —

F.Choice: the Leaning Tower of Pisa has been flawed since its construction, but the Cutty Sark functioned well for many years

Key.Rationale: The lean of the tower was detected during early construction, but the Cutty Sark was refurbished after the ship had served the Royal Navy and had set new speed records.

G.Choice: the Leaning Tower of Pisa has achieved fame in recent years, but the Cutty Sark was famous from the time it was built

Key.Rationale: The Leaning Tower of Pisa was famous from the time construction began.

H.Choice: the work on the Leaning Tower of Pisa is finished, but the work on the Cutty Sark is ongoing

Key.Rationale: More work may be necessary in the future, but the renovation of the Cutty Sark was completed before the display was opened to the public in 2012.

J.Choice: the Leaning Tower of Pisa can no longer be used as a bell tower, but the Cutty Sark can still be used for some of its original purposes

Key.Rationale: The tower was reopened to the public after the 1990 effort to level the ground underneath the structure. The Cutty Sark is no longer in use; it is displayed in London.

Content: Read this sentence from “Reinforcing the Past.”
:box:In 1934 an attempt to stabilize the tower included injecting concrete into the stone foundation, but some of the concrete seeped under the foundation, causing the tower to lean even more.
Which sentence from “The Cutty Sark” relates a similar idea?

A.Choice: A clipper is a fast sailing ship, and the Cutty Sark's sleek hull made it ideal to serve in the tea trade between China and England.

Key.Rationale: This description of the Cutty Sark does not relate to the attempt to stabilize the tower.

B.Choice: The trust closed the ship to the public in 2006, and an architectural firm began a long conservation project.

Key.Rationale: The conservation project involving the Cutty Sark was undertaken to prevent deterioration, and the attempt to stabilize the tower resulted in the structure leaning more.

C.Choice: Unfortunately, during the renovation in 2007, the ship caught fire when a vacuum cleaner was left on.

Key.Rationale: Both the tower and the Cutty Sark were damaged, resulting in repairs to the structures.

D.Choice: The clipper was later used for training officers who served in the Royal Navy in World War II.

Key.Rationale: The use of the Cutty Sark for training officers during World War II does not result in an effort to refurbish the ship.

Content: One difference between the efforts to preserve the Leaning Tower of Pisa and those of the Cutty Sark is that the efforts related to the Cutty Sark included  —

F.Choice: fixing the structure in a way that allowed it to perform its original function

Key.Rationale: The purpose of refurbishing the hull of the Cutty Sark was to prepare it for display. The ship is no longer in use.

G.Choice: finding a way to increase the number of people visiting the structure

Key.Rationale: The exhibit of the Cutty Sark attracts visitors from around the world.

H.Choice: changing the way the structure was displayed

Key.Rationale: The hull of the Cutty Sark was renovated so visitors could view the shape of the hull. The purpose of efforts to stabilize the tower was to keep the tower from collapsing.

J.Choice: repairing specific parts of the structure

Key.Rationale: The conservation efforts for the ship prevented deterioration, but the purpose of the renovation was not to repair specific parts of the structure.

Content: The authors of both selections share the history of their subjects in chronological order to emphasize that  —

A.Choice: structures can quickly fall into a state of disrepair if they are not properly maintained

Key.Rationale: The repair of the tower involved the ground underneath and not the structure itself, and the ship never fell into a state of disrepair.

B.Choice: there is an ongoing debate about the best ways to restore historical structures

Key.Rationale: There is no ongoing debate about the best way to restore historical structures.

C.Choice: the restoration of the structures takes less time when the projects are adequately funded

Key.Rationale: The selections do not address the issue of funding for the restoration of structures.

D.Choice: the significance of the structures has been recognized for a long time

Key.Rationale: Both the tower and ship contributed to the history of the countries where they originated.

Content: In the first stanza, the poet suggests that one reason the poplar is not useful is that it  —

F.Choice: loses its leaves in the fall

Key.Rationale: The poem does not indicate that the trees lose their leaves in the fall.

G.Choice: does not provide much protection for others

Key.Rationale: The tree does not have wide branches that would provide protection for birds and squirrels or shade for people who pass.

H.Choice: does not grow very tall

Key.Rationale: The poem does not indicate the height of the tree.

J.Choice: grows in areas where few other things live

Key.Rationale: The poem does not indicate where the tree grows.

Content: The poet uses personification in the fourth stanza to describe the poplar's attempt to  —

A.Choice: attract visitors

Key.Rationale: The poem personifies the branches trying to attract visitors.

B.Choice: remain active

Key.Rationale: Personification in the fourth stanza does not indicate the poplar's attempts to stay active.

C.Choice: provide directions to others

Key.Rationale: The poplar in the poem does not provide directions to others.

D.Choice: resist being moved by the wind

Key.Rationale: The fourth stanza the poplar moves effortlessly and purposefully to welcome children and birds.

Content: Line 1 is important to the poem because it helps  —

F.Choice: introduce a familiar setting

Key.Rationale: Line 1 does not indicate the setting of the poem.

G.Choice: describe the speaker

Key.Rationale: Line 1 does not address the speaker of the poem.

H.Choice: create imagery

Key.Rationale: Line 1 does not include sensory language.

J.Choice: establish the mood

Key.Rationale: Line 1 establishes the mood of the poem with the statement that the poplar tree is lonely.

Content: In stanza 2, the poplar is described mainly as  —

A.Choice: cautious

Key.Rationale: Stanza 2 does not describe the poplar tree as cautious.

B.Choice: envious

Key.Rationale: Stanza 2 describes a neighboring tree that has the benefits longed for by the poplar in stanza 1.

C.Choice: curious

Key.Rationale: There is no evidence in stanza 2 that the poplar was curious.

D.Choice: arrogant

Key.Rationale: There is no evidence in stanza 2 that the poplar is arrogant.

Content: Why is the last stanza important to the poem?

F.Choice: It suggests that the poplar may become a desirable tree.

Key.Rationale: The last stanza does not suggest the poplar tree will change in any way.

G.Choice: It shows how a poplar copes with its situation.

Key.Rationale: The poplar tree copes with loneliness by growing close together with other poplar trees.

H.Choice: It implies that the poplar wants to be a unique tree.

Key.Rationale: There is no evidence the poplar tree expresses a desire to be a unique tree.

J.Choice: It provides an explanation for the size of a poplar.

Key.Rationale: The last stanza does not include an explanation for the size of a poplar tree.

Content: By describing qualities that the poplar lacks, the poet emphasizes  —

A.Choice: why the poplar is unappealing to others

Key.Rationale: The poplar's narrow branches and lack of shade indicate why the birds, squirrels, and visitors are not drawn to the tree.

B.Choice: how the poplar is affected by its environment

Key.Rationale: The poet does not include information about the ways the poplar's environment affects the tree.

C.Choice: why the poplar grows near different types of trees

Key.Rationale: The poet does not explain the reason why the poplar tree grows near different types of trees.

D.Choice: how the poplar finds relief from its problem

Key.Rationale: The poplar does not find relief from its problem in the poem; the tree copes with its problem.

Content: Why does the playwright include the stage directions in paragraph 22?

F.Choice: To imply that Asia is taking the task of cutting Lonnie's hair seriously

Key.Rationale: The stage directions in paragraph 22 do not indicate Asia is taking the task of cutting Lonnie's hair seriously.

G.Choice: To indicate that both Lonnie and Asia are nervous about the haircut

Key.Rationale: Lonnie and Asia both close their eyes tightly during the process to indicate their nervousness.

H.Choice: To reveal that Asia has more experience cutting hair than she said she did

Key.Rationale: The stage directions in paragraph 22 do not address Asia's experience with cutting hair.

J.Choice: To show that Asia is pleased she has a chance to cut someone's hair

Key.Rationale: Asia closes her eyes and cuts, and then she lets out a deep breath after she finishes. This does not indicate Asia is pleased to have the chance to cut someone's hair.

Content: Why does Lonnie agree to let Asia cut her hair?

A.Choice: Lonnie decides that a free haircut from Asia is better than paying for a salon haircut.

Key.Rationale: Iin paragraph 17 Asia convinces Lonnie that Lonnie should not pay for a salon haircut.

B.Choice: Lonnie trusts that Asia's father has taught Asia how to cut hair properly.

Key.Rationale: In paragraph 16 Lonnie realizes Asia has never really cut anyone's hair.

C.Choice: Lonnie knows Asia has access to the right tools for cutting hair.

Key.Rationale: The only tool Asia uses is a pair of scissors. This is not why Lonnie agrees to let Asia cut her hair.

D.Choice: Lonnie believes that her hair will look just like the style she wants if Asia cuts it.

Key.Rationale: Lonnie asks Asia to start by just trimming Lonnie's hair so Lonnie can then decide if she wants Asia to continue.

Content: What does the word g͟u͟s͟t͟o mean in paragraph 25?

F.Choice: Concern

Key.Rationale: Asia smiles and sings as she cuts Lonnie's hair.

G.Choice: Precision

Key.Rationale: Asia stops singing and snipping and stares at Lonnie's hair.

H.Choice: Curiosity

Key.Rationale: There is no evidence in paragraph 25 that Asia or Lonnie were curious.

J.Choice: Enthusiasm

Key.Rationale: Asia's smiling, singing, and snipping while she cuts Lonnie's hair reflect her enthusiasm for the task.

Content: What is the best summary of the play?

A.Choice: Asia and Lonnie look through magazines and notice a hairstyle worn by a singer they like. Lonnie wants her hair cut in that style, and Asia tells Lonnie she has watched her father cut hair. Lonnie agrees to let Asia cut her hair. While Asia is cutting hair, her brother comes in and out of the room looking for his baseball bat. Asia finishes Lonnie's haircut, but Lonnie says it is terrible.

Key.Rationale: This summary does not include the resolution of the story.

B.Choice: Lonnie sees a hairstyle she likes in a magazine and agrees to let Asia cut her hair. Lonnie worries when Asia won't give her a mirror and Jeremiah comments on her appearance. Asia tries to improve the haircut, but Lonnie is upset when she finally gets to see it. Asia tries to make Lonnie feel better, and the girls agree to get matching haircuts together at a salon.

Key.Rationale: This summary contains all of the important events from the story.

C.Choice: Asia and Lonnie are looking through magazines when they decide they like a singer's hairstyle. Asia suggests that she can cut Lonnie's hair to look like the style in the magazine. Asia persuades Lonnie to let her do it by saying that she has seen her father cut hair many times. After Asia finishes, the girls plan to go to the salon together to get matching haircuts.

Key.Rationale: This summary does not include the result of Asia's haircutting task.

D.Choice: Lonnie wants a haircut like the one she sees in a magazine. Asia offers to cut her hair for free, and Lonnie agrees to let her. Jeremiah, Asia's brother, makes comments about Lonnie's hair that worry her. When Lonnie finally sees her finished haircut, she blames Asia for ruining it. She tells Asia to put on the apron so that Lonnie can cut her hair with the same style.

Key.Rationale: It contains information not in the play.

Content: Why does the playwright include the sensory language in paragraph 43?

F.Choice: To show the reader that Lonnie is overreacting to the situation

Key.Rationale: Paragraph 43 does not indicate Lonnie's response to the haircut was overreacting.

G.Choice: To allow the reader to better visualize the style of the haircut

Key.Rationale: Paragraph 43 does not address the style of the haircut.

H.Choice: To help the reader understand how distraught Lonnie feels

Key.Rationale: Lonnie's response and watering eyes indicate how distraught she feels.

J.Choice: To tell the reader that Lonnie puts a lot of thought into her hairstyle

Key.Rationale: Paragraph 43 does not indicate that Lonnie puts a lot of thought into her hairstyle.

Content: Asia's dialogue in paragraph 51 is important because it shows that she  —

A.Choice: appreciates having a chance to practice cutting hair

Key.Rationale: Paragraph 51 does not address Asia's feelings about cutting hair.

B.Choice: is envious of how good her friend's hair looks now

Key.Rationale: Paragraph 51 does not indicate Asia is jealous of Lonnie's hairstyle.

C.Choice: prefers having her hair cut by a professional

Key.Rationale: In paragraph 51 Asia's decision to go to the salon is a part of her apology to Lonnie.

D.Choice: wants to be supportive of her friend

Key.Rationale: Asia decides to get her hair cut into the same style as Lonnie's to show that Asia is supportive of her friend.

Content: What can the reader infer about Asia and Lonnie based on how the play ends?

F.Choice: Asia and Lonnie will get into trouble for the mess that they made.

Key.Rationale: There is no textual evidence that Asia and Lonnie will be in trouble for making a mess.

G.Choice: Asia and Lonnie will have their hair cut only by professionals in the future.

Key.Rationale: The author does not address a plan for Asia and Lonnie to get all their future haircuts at a salon.

H.Choice: Asia and Lonnie will continue to be friends despite what has happened.

Key.Rationale: Asia smiles as she and Lonnie discuss how they will respond to similar problems in the future.

J.Choice: Asia will choose a hairstyle different from the one Lonnie chose.

Key.Rationale: The author does not provide information about the hairstyles Asia and Lonnie choose.
